simple_summary.what_happened: Two critical zero-day vulnerabilities were discovered in Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM), the enterprise platform used to manage corporate mobile devices. Attackers found they could inject malicious commands through HTTP requests without needing any login credentials. The flaws were already being exploited before Ivanti even knew about them, with attackers installing backdoors and reverse shells on compromised servers. A public proof-of-concept exploit is now available, dramatically increasing the risk.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Any organization running on-premises Ivanti EPMM (formerly MobileIron Core) for mobile device management. This includes enterprises, government agencies, healthcare organizations, and military networks that rely on EPMM to manage employee smartphones and tablets. Cloud-hosted Ivanti Neurons for MDM is NOT affected.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attackers send specially crafted HTTP GET requests to EPMM endpoints for app distribution or Android file transfer. Step 2: Malicious Bash commands embedded in the requests bypass all authentication checks. Step 3: The commands execute with EPMM service privileges on the underlying server. Step 4: Attackers install webshells (often modifying error pages like 401.jsp) and deploy WAR/JAR files for persistent reverse shell connections. Step 5: With full server access, attackers harvest administrator credentials, user data, email addresses, phone numbers, IMEI numbers, GPS locations, and can pivot to internal networks via the EPMM API.
what_you_should_do: Apply Ivanti RPM hotfix scripts immediately - no downtime required
If your EPMM was internet-exposed before patching, assume compromise and initiate incident response
Search Apache access logs for exploitation attempts using Ivanti's detection regex pattern
Check for unauthorized webshells especially in error pages like 401.jsp
Look for unexpected WAR or JAR files and outbound network connections from EPMM
Reset all local EPMM passwords, LDAP/KDC service accounts, and public certificates
Review Sentry logs for signs of lateral movement
If compromise is confirmed, restore from known-good backup or rebuild the EPMM appliance
Plan upgrade to EPMM 12.8.0.0 when released in Q1 2026 for permanent fix
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: EPMM manages the entire mobile device fleet of an organization. Compromise gives attackers access to every managed device's data including GPS locations, phone numbers, installed apps, and IMEI numbers. Attackers can also modify device authentication policies via the EPMM API, potentially pushing malicious configurations to thousands of corporate devices simultaneously. This is the third time EPMM has been hit with zero-days in three years, and a public exploit is now available, meaning mass exploitation is imminent.

tactics.description: Unauthenticated command injection via HTTP GET requests to EPMM app distribution and file transfer endpoints

tactics.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell
tactics.description: Bash commands injected through crafted HTTP requests execute on the underlying EPMM server
Attackers install webshells by modifying error pages like 401.jsp for persistent access
Deployment of malicious WAR/JAR files for persistent reverse shell connections
EPMM stores administrator credentials, LDAP service account details, and device certificates
Mass harvesting of PII including names, emails, phone numbers, IMEI, MAC addresses, and GPS coordinates from managed devices
Pivoting from compromised EPMM appliance to internal network using harvested credentials

detection_guidance.summary: Focus detection efforts on Apache access logs for the EPMM appliance, specifically monitoring the In-House Application Distribution and Android File Transfer Configuration endpoints. Look for anomalous HTTP GET requests with Bash command patterns, unexpected 404 responses, and any outbound network connections from the EPMM server which should not normally occur.

log_sources.description: HTTP request logs showing access to /mifs/c/appstore/fob/ and /mifs/c/aftstore/fob/ endpoints
EPMM service logs for authentication events and API calls
Outbound connection attempts from EPMM appliance - these should not normally occur
Changes to JSP files, new WAR/JAR deployments on the EPMM appliance
Monitor for lateral movement indicators from compromised EPMM

what_to_look_for.indicator: Exploitation attempt on app distribution endpoint
what_to_look_for.description: External requests to /mifs/c/appstore/fob/ or /mifs/c/aftstore/fob/ returning 404 status codes indicate potential exploitation
what_to_look_for.log_field: request_uri MATCHES '/mifs/c/(aft|app)store/fob/' AND status='404' AND src_ip!='127.0.0.1'

what_to_look_for.indicator: Bash command patterns in HTTP requests
what_to_look_for.description: GET requests containing shell metacharacters or common command patterns
what_to_look_for.log_field: request_uri CONTAINS 'bash' OR request_uri CONTAINS '$((' OR request_uri CONTAINS 'curl' OR request_uri CONTAINS 'wget'

what_to_look_for.description: Changes to JSP error pages especially 401.jsp indicate webshell installation
what_to_look_for.log_field: file_modified='401.jsp' OR method='POST' AND request_uri CONTAINS '401.jsp'

what_to_look_for.description: EPMM appliance initiating connections to external IPs, indicating reverse shell activity
what_to_look_for.log_field: src_ip=EPMM_IP AND direction='outbound' AND dst_port NOT IN (443, 80, 53)

what_to_look_for.description: Unexpected Java archive files appearing on the EPMM appliance filesystem

immediate_actions.description: Install the appropriate RPM script for your EPMM version. Use RPM 12.x.0.x for versions 12.5.0.x, 12.6.0.x, 12.7.0.x. Use RPM 12.x.1.x for versions 12.5.1.0, 12.6.1.0. No downtime required. Note: RPM must be reapplied after version upgrades.
If your EPMM instance was accessible from the internet before patching, assume compromise. Search Apache access logs with Ivanti's regex pattern to identify exploitation attempts.
Check for modified JSP error pages and unexpected WAR/JAR files that indicate attacker persistence.
EPMM should not make outbound network connections. Any outbound traffic indicates potential reverse shell activity.
Change passwords for local EPMM accounts, LDAP/KDC service accounts, and regenerate public certificates to limit attacker persistence.
Ensure the EPMM management interface is not directly accessible from the internet. Use VPN or IP allowlists.
If evidence of compromise is found, restore from a known-good backup or rebuild the EPMM appliance entirely, then migrate data to the clean instance.
